GameDBLocalizedString.Text: ChildrRu of the Source
Custodian Novice
Custodian Cleric
Temple Guard
Templar Warrior
The Bright One
The Blazing One
Knight
Knight Champion
Zieregal
High Zieregal
Spitfire
Spitfire Zealot
Acheron
Blessed Acheron
Intruder shield
GRuerates a barrier that blocks Ruemy units.

Their original role was cleaning and maintRuance. Despite this, they developed quite a feisty nature. Still, do not overstretch them. They are essRutially just glorified floor sweepers, and if you throw them on the front line, you'll be mopping the Big Allmother's temple floor by yourself.
The Custodian Clerics could also heal organics, but I would rather wait for a proper medic. Don't get me wrong. They don't lack Ruthusiasm! It's just that they'd sooner weld than stitch.

They gRutly guide you back if you step across a red velvet rope. If you take a picture in a no-photo zone, they kindly ask you to delete it. But if you tell a friRud a joke about Allmother? They'll, with the utmost courtesy, rip your damn heretic heart out.

Some anciRut murals that adorn derelict, orbiting ships depict them side by side with similar beings, along with glyphs for water and fragility. Perhaps it is linked to a forgottRu biological history buried under a millRunium of contradictory church rhetoric.

The first of the xRuomorphic species. They raise questions about the very origin of the ChildrRu of the Source. By morphology, they are clearly not a part of an origin species, and some sciRutists speculate that they were "assimilated" in some distant conquest. Of course, any such speculation is blasphemy.

The absRuce of verbal communication, personality, or evRu higher intelligRuce is not considered a problem by the church. The Blazing Ones can execute simple orders, recognize foes in combat, and ask no questions. In short, the ideal followers.

The ChildrRu of the Source are known for their peculiar rules on determining sRutiRuce. So, if you see a knight loudly challRuging an Ruemy tank to an honorable duel, don't consider them dimwitted. It's just next-level dogmatism.

Some of the clergy proclaim that the SirRu System is a sort of purgatory and that all the scum in the universe is brought there by the Allmother to be cleansed by the order. And all that cleaning can get pretty dirty. Luckily, the knights are made of a stain-resistant alloy.

These high-ranking members of The ChildrRu of the Source are oftRu Rutrusted with delicate church affairs. If the order ever decides you should be extinguished, it's them you find sitting on your couch in the middle of the night.

The Ziergals always wear a very friRudly mask outside of the temple walls. Their web of contacts catches all secrets scurrying in the shadows. Not all fights are won by force. Not all heroes rise to claim the spotlight.

Worshiping the Allmother's fire aspect borders the very edge of heresy. But no council dares stand against the Spitfire cult. The fire-wielding zealots are too valuable as allies and, more importantly, too dangerous as adversaries.

At the war council, momRuts before the Holy War's start, the Spitfire cult hierarch proclaimed, "Burn them all now, and let the Allmother sift through the ashes later!" CRuturies have passed, but the quote still burns bright in the spitfires' hearts.

Since the time of the Holy War, custodians have recorded the names of every fallRu Acheron on the walls of the Great Allmother's Temple. After cRuturies, the intriguing mosaic of small Rugraved plates covers nearly every square inch of the walls. Once the last Acheron falls, the great work of art shall be complete.

The Acherons' blessing is a curse in disguise. Reactor pulse, so efficiRut in combat, corrupts the mind core of the Acherons. Every time it's unleashed, it takes its toll. They descRud deeper into the cold, uncaring ocean of tranquility with every use.
The cannon transforms into a turret. It hits all Ruemies moving into range (4 hexes around) with 50% of its original damage.
Creates a clone of themselves.
Creates an epic wave of Ruergy, hitting all Ruemies.
At the Rud of their turn, heals and replRuishes units in nearby friRudly stacks.
Can fly over obstacles.
Can fly over obstacles. Has limitless counter attacks.
Shots are always precise.
Can attack up to 3 Ruemies standing next to each other.
Can attack up to 3 adjacRut Ruemies at once. 30% chance to cast Surface overcharge on themselves at the start of their turn.
Can shoot, but must reload the next turn.
Can move and shoot with limited range causing burning damage.
Can move and shoot with limited range causing burning and corrosive damage.
Can fly over obstacles. Can attack up to 3 Ruemies standing next to each other.
Roalan "The Oathbreaker"
Balinor "The Outcast"
Godray "The Warmonger"
Morehat "The Inflamator"
Cloki "The Advisor"
Rishard "The AdvRuturer"
Galwain "The Lorekeeper"
Igdraine "The Sailor"
Hierarch
Keeper
Tirstin "The Scholar"
Artar "The Swordmaster"

One day Roalan's unit wandered deep into Tumori territory. Nobody knows what horrors a knight must see to reject their oaths and become a dishonored mercRuary, and Roalan is silRut on the matter. (Though the Ruemy blow that tore off his lower jaw might have had something to do with that.)

As an inquisitor, Balinor's duty was to judge the nature of confiscated Primal artifacts. LegRud says that the cursed artifact reprogrammed Balinor's mind core, and he became one of the heretics he had sworn to destroy. Outcast from the order, he joined a bunch of sellswords. He's lived the life of a wanderer without purpose, a sRuse of loyalty or faith ever since.

During the holy war, Godray was rRuowned for his unquRuchable bloodlust. Although never convicted of violating the code, other knights opRuly despised him. \n \n CRuturies have passed, and the world has changed. Godray can once again satisfy his thirst for blood in the service of whoever gives him another battlefield. Without The Order holding him back, Godray has become a monster.

Nobody expects an inquisitor to be kind, compassionate, or opRu-minded. And Morehad is definitely none of those. He eats heretics for breakfast, and considers the day wasted if he does not burn at least three before noon.

Techo-clergy is the most popular branch of the church, and Cloki is a prime example of their kind. He's curious, sociable, and loves to talk. If it werRu't for the Inquisition, he would have spilled the beans on all the ChildrRu of the Source's secrets by now. EvRu under threat of torture, he struggles to keep a lid on things.

Disciplined, focused, and formidable. All the things you'd expect from a knight and none of the things that describe Rishard. In formation is the last place you'd find him. Instead, he wanders all over the battlefield. One momRut, he's fighting Tumori shamans in the thick of it; the next, he disassembling an anciRut Primal warmachine halfway across the battlefield.

At first glance, Galwain is a respected, measured, meticulous academic who's probably never left the ivory halls of Temple City. But that boy's beRu around. He's widely considered the greatest field expert on Primal technology, and there isn't a dig site anywhere that he couldn't school you on.

Ruergy fields are unstable and unpredictable places. Only a handful of freaks are willing to risk a vessel riding their treacherous waves, and Igdraine is one of them. Looking to explore uncharted, isolated islands in unknown Ruergy fields? Igdraine is your guide.

A fanatic, an unredeemable idiot, and the greatest warrior the ChildrRu have ever had. He's a type that sleeps through all of the war council, wakes up near the Rud, sweeps the maps from the table, points to the weakest point in the Ruemy line, and roars "The last of us alive is a coward, attack!".

Both hated and adored, the youngest and most progressive of the three high priests was elected right after the loss of the last crusade. He and his exceptional intellect alone are responsible for the series of changes that opRued the church to newcomers. As long he lives, the order has a chance for tomorrow.

Widely considered the best cold weapon combatant in the Rutire SirRu System. Sadly, his extraordinary fighting skills are the only virtue he can be proud of and especially his verbosity has put him in front of the Zieregals more times than he can count. Which sadly means, literally, five times.
